div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,707] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, MARCH 11, 1907. [EIGHT PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Venice Trieste. Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria Saturdays 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi Tuesdays 5 a.m. in time for Express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival at Venice Wednesday about 9.30 a.m. Passengers may proceed from Venice to Switzerland, Paris and London by the 2 p.m. and 11.5 p.m. – Expresses. Arrival at Trieste Wednesday about 3 p.m. in connection with the Train de Luxe proceeding the same evening to Vienna, Frankfort, Cologne, Brussel, Ostende and London. Arrival at London every Friday 5.12 p.m.

div.head: THE NATIONAL HOTEL, Cairo
div.p: One of the finest and most up-to-date Hotels in the Metropolis. Situated in Sharia Soliman Pasha, the very centre of the healthiest and most fashionable quarter. Stands in its own grounds with garden and lawn tennis grounds at back. Over 350 rooms and 5 saloons. Magnificent salle à manger. Handsome covered promenade verandah, 80 yards long. Highest class cuisine, electric light throughout, and lifts. English comforts. Rooms and apartments at prices to suit everyone. For further particulars apply to GENERAL MANAGER, Cairo.

MONDAY, MARCH 11, 1907

The “Shipping World” (Feb. 20) takes the “Melbourne Age" to task for “irrelevance, inaccuracies, end abuse,” affecting the attitude of His Majesty's Government on the subject of the 8uez Canal chargee. Says the “Shipping World" “It haa eacaped -our contemporary that, under the Articles of Association or the constitution of the [Suez Canal] Company, no shareholder can hare more than ten votes, and that the Government is, rightly or wrongly, treated as a single shareholder. There are 400,000 shares, and Of this total we bold 176,602, so that io voting power, even assum- ing that every vote could be polled, we would ’till be in a minority. Moreover, when loans are counted, the capital account stands at about £19,000,000, or about six times the amount of the British investment.............................

We continue to hold that the earnings and dividends of the Company, the bulk of them coming from British shipowners,- should be reduced, and that 28 per cent, is more than a great international highway should pay. But here, again, there is an­other side to the shield. The dividend .to the man who bought shares this year or last year is only about 2} per cent,, and the rights of recent purchasers are factors which should not be lost sight of. And possibly Mr. Asquith, and certainly many taxpayers, would be reluctant to reduce the million sterling now received in dividends from the Canal Com­pany. To say that Australian fruit or butter— especially such expensive stuff ss butter—pays any considerable part of the Suez dues is not consistent with fact. Like’ Customs duties, tolls are paid by the people who pay them. We must protest, further, against such words as ‘Here, in the Suez business, we have an example of the manner in which Great Britain knows how to fleece all thoae who deal with her, and more especially her Colonies.’ That is simply nonsense."

It seems that lawyers and authorities on international law are at variance on the ques­tion of whether the Suez Company has or haa not the exclusive right to construct and work any or every possible canal between the Medi­terranean and the Red Sea. The “Shipping World" suggests that it would be quite useful for some member of Parliament to extract something definite from His Majesty’s legal advisers on this point. “If this exclusive right does not exist, we ought to try to obtain a concession for a second canal Any­body who goes into the figures will find that, even if it cost twice 'as much as did the first, it would repay us—and it would be ours. But if the reply is. that the present company haa such an exclusive right, or if we find it impossible to obtain a concession (the obtaining of which would not be facilitated by our most unfor­tunate attitude in Egypt, and our persistent abuse of the very astute ruler of the chief Mohamedan state), then there still remain other means. A ship railway was seriously considered for Tehuantepec, and a railway specially adapted for ship to ship traffic has just been opened there. An improvement of the Nile navigation, either by Alexandria, Damietta, or Rosetta to Cairo, and a canal . thence to Suez, is within the range of both engineering and financial possibility ; though, no doubt, a second canal would be preferable. The inevitable El Arish railway has yet to be constructed ; where a railway can be made, possibly a canal may bo. There is a Gulf at Akaba as well as at Suez. Such works as are here hinted at would be nothing very wonder­ful in a land of wonders—of pyramids, of Assouan dams, and of Suez Canals. Let us question the head of Memnon. and solve the riddle of the Sphinx ”

| In 1882 British shipping through the Suez Cansl was over four million tons ; in 1906 it had risen to eight and a half millions. In 1882 German shipping was 127,000 tons ; in 1906, two and a quarter millions. In 1882 England owned 81 per cent, of all shipping passing through the Canal, in 1906 the percentage had sunk to 63, In 1882 Germany owned 2) per , but in 1906 this bad risen to over 16

French, German, Italian, Greek, Arabic, etc.
